questions.stem: What information should appear on a report title page?
questions.rationale: Title pages should include the report title, author(s), organization, and date.

questions.stem: How should the title be positioned on the title page?

options.label: At the bottom of the page

questions.rationale: The title should be centered both vertically and horizontally on the page.

questions.stem: The title page should not include a _____ number.
questions.rationale: Title pages are not numbered as part of the report pagination.

questions.stem: What should be included in a table of contents?

options.label: All headings and subheadings with page numbers

questions.rationale: Include all major headings and significant subheadings with corresponding page numbers.

questions.stem: How should page numbers be shown in the table of contents?
questions.rationale: Page numbers should be right-aligned, typically with dot leaders connecting to headings.

questions.stem: When is a table of contents necessary?

options.label: In reports with multiple sections or over 10 pages

questions.rationale: Include a table of contents when the report has multiple sections or exceeds about 10 pages.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of an executive summary?

options.label: To provide key findings and recommendations

questions.rationale: Executive summaries highlight key findings, conclusions, and recommendations for busy readers.

questions.stem: How long should an executive summary typically be?
questions.rationale: Executive summaries should be concise, typically one to two pages regardless of report length.

questions.stem: Should an executive summary include new information not in the report?

options.label: No, it should only summarize existing content

questions.rationale: Executive summaries should only contain information that appears in the full report.

questions.stem: How should report headings be formatted?

options.label: In a clear hierarchy with consistent formatting

questions.rationale: Use a clear hierarchy of headings with consistent formatting to show document structure.

questions.stem: What elements help create clear report structure? (Select all that apply)
questions.rationale: Clear structure requires numbered headings, consistent formatting, logical flow, and adequate white space.

questions.stem: Each major section should begin with a _____ that introduces the content.
questions.rationale: Topic sentences or introductory paragraphs help orient readers to each section's content.

questions.stem: What type of information belongs in appendices?

options.label: Supporting material that would interrupt the flow

questions.rationale: Appendices contain supporting material that would interrupt the main text flow if included.
Appendices are typically labeled alphabetically: Appendix A, Appendix B, etc.

questions.stem: Should appendices be mentioned in the main text?

options.label: Only in the table of contents

questions.rationale: Reference appendices in the main text so readers know when to consult them.

questions.stem: What information must be included in meeting minutes?

options.label: Date, attendees, decisions, and action items

questions.rationale: Minutes should record date, attendees, decisions made, and action items assigned.

questions.stem: How should action items be recorded in minutes?

options.label: In a separate section with clear assignments
In an email after the meeting

questions.rationale: Action items should be clearly identified with responsible parties and deadlines.

questions.stem: Click on what's missing from this minute entry:
questions.text: John reported on budget status. Discussion followed.
questions.rationale: Missing the actual content of John's report and any decisions or outcomes.

questions.stem: What spacing should be used for report text?
questions.rationale: 1.5 line spacing provides good readability for most report formats.
